posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

From the 1500s to the 1800s, in Eastern Orthodoxy you could purchase indulgences called "Absolution Certificates," in which you would pay a certain amount of money to your bishop and he would issue you a written absolution of sin, for you or someone else, with no repentance required. So you could literally pay to have your sins forgiven.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indulgence#Eastern_Orthodox_Church
https://orthodoxwiki.org/Absolution_Certificates

>These certificates were real indulgences that anyone could obtain which absolved them from sin. These were often obtainable for a specified amounts of money. ... the absolution granted by these certificates had no connection with any participation by the faithful in the Mystery of Penance, nor in the Mystery of the Eucharist.

>Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem Dositheos Notaras (1641–1707) wrote: "It is an established custom and ancient tradition, known to all, that the Most Holy Patriarchs give the absolution certificate (συγχωροχάρτιον – synchorochartion) to the faithful people … they have granted them from the beginning and still do."

>The practice of issuing indulgences ... received official confirmation at the Constantinople Council of 1727. ... "The Confession of Faith" from the Council, the text of which was compiled by Patriarch Chrysanthus of Jerusalem and was signed by Patriarchs Paisius II of Constantinople, Sylvester of Antioch, and Chrysanthus of Jerusalem ... said, "The power of the forgiveness of sins, which is termed by the Eastern Church of Christ Absolution Certificates when given in writing, but by the Latins Indulgences, is given to the Holy Church by Christ. These Absolution Certificates are issued in the whole Catholic Church by the four most holy Patriarchs: Constantinople, Alexandria, Antioch, and Jerusalem."

>Indulgences as a means of enrichment were condemned at the Council of Constantinople in the year 1838.

>>14384181
Complex grammar (at least to some minimum standard) has been pretty much universal for millennia, even hunter-gatherers have it. If anything they often have more complex languages; the languages spoken by big settled civilizations are worn down by being learned by a bunch of adults who acquire them imperfectly, while languages of small hunter-gatherer tribes have no such factor keeping them simple. That's why Navajo is freakishly complex while English and Mandarin are relatively simple by comparison (though still more complex than pidgins or creoles).

>>14391974
Is there truth? I think there probably is because I believe there's an objective universe, based on my observations. I could be wrong though. Due to the problem of induction, I reckon we can't be truly certain of anything. We just have to make our best guesses at knowledge.

>but what about a priori knowledge?
"All bachelors are unmarried men"... you might say that's a priori true, and as such is not subject to the problem of induction. But what if, in 100 years' time, the meaning of the word "bachelor" has changed? What if ends up including women too? (Like the word "actor" is now used for women as well.) So really I think all knowledge is empirical, including the definition of the word "bachelor".

Also think about "2 + 2 = 4". That won't be true anymore if the meaning of "4" changes. But also, I would argue that "2 + 2 = 4" expresses an observation about the universe. It could be that adding two pairs of things caused a fifth thing to pop into existence. Then "2 + 2 = 5" would be true. But that isn't the case. So we're expressing empirical knowledge when we say "2 + 2 = 4".

Atheism and religions are different classes of objects. >>14392118
>For example, the US had vastly superior systems of supply for most of its wars against gorillas
To add to the guy who said wars were won mostly by will and logistics we need to add another important variable, which is strategy. If one has declared war against something like "terror," or if one has poorly defined or impossible goals, then they have severely burdened their fighting force.

Consequently, the reason why a weaker side might still fight a war is because their war goals could be completely different, time might be on their side due to the differing strategies involved. They might just have to hold their ground and be on the defensive to win, while the other side has to extend into dangerous territory and expose themselves more to the elements of attrition. So even if one has excellent logistics to help avoid an all-out catastrophe, and even if one has a far greater force than the other side, one can still lose to attrition anyway. Things like winter weather and disease can still ravage a force, regardless of supply lines. We saw this for instance in the Crimean war, which saw massive attrition to disease, the horrendous result of which led to much more focus by the Europeans on medical attention being available on future battlefields. The fact that newspapers at the time were beginning to be able to report on battlefield conditions to the rest of the world relatively quickly, probably also spurred this development.

So, applying this to the example of Vietnam, we can see that the gorillas just had to outlast an opponent who was strategically unwilling to escalate the conflict beyond a certain point. This could be seen not as a logistical failure as much as a strategic one, because the goal of winning without escalating beyond a certain point proved impossible, therefore turning the theater into an endless meat grinder. And even if they had battlefield success to report on, that wouldn't change this problem.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14396077
Take perpetual virginity for example. This isn't directly taught in Scripture, and the evidence regarding Jesus's brothers can, at least linguistically, be understood either way. There are prophetic elements that can come to bear, e.g. Eze. 44:2, but they are not directly applied to Mary in the text. Also there is the intertexual implication of Mary as the antitype of the Ark of the Covenant, e.g. in Luke, which would render Mary as having at least some sort of inviolability, I would think. But is applying those concepts to Mary legitimate? I think it is, because if you don't the situation becomes problematic. Mary's perpetual virginity is understood to be threefold, which is that she was a virgin before, during, and after giving birth to Christ. So the miracle of the Virgin Birth has a great fullness than simply referring to the act of conception. Her virginity before birth is not disputed. Her virginity during birth means that Christ was not just conceived by a miraculous means, but also born by one, as his birth did not injure his mother but left her virginity physically intact. If this was not the case, then it means Christ's birth destroyed Mary's physical virginity, which is too impious to seriously consider. Most don't consider this, though, I think, when they reject perpetual virginity -- so I'm not making an accusation of impiety to anyone. But this is a legitimate concern that gives license to read the texts differently, in a manner that is piously concerned with not imputing such a thing to God and his mother. And if you do that, it justifies the third point, of her virginity after birth, as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14392913
Because unlike Latin which fractured into numerous Romance languages following the power vacuum created by the decline of the Western Roman Empire, Greek dialects/languages (such as Aeolic, Doric, NW Doric, Attic, Ionic, Arcadocypriot, and likely Macedonian though this could also be a very divergent Doric/NW Doric dialect similiar to Epirote) was purposefully standardized to Koine Greek, which was retained even after the downfall of Macedon. And after the Roman conquest, Greeks by and large lived in the same state (Eastern Rome), with only peripheries splitting off and becoming divergent dialects (Silliot, Pharasiot, Cappadocian, Pontic, Italiot, Cypriot, Cretan, etc.).
Political unity during the Byzantine Era prevented Greek from becoming a pluricentric language like Latin did, before those dialects diverged enough or became prestigious enough to be considered languages.

>>14389660
>How should I educate her and stoke an interest in it? I don't even know where to start.

Fundamentally, people only get into history because they're *actually* interested in a specific subject of history: Agriculture, Religion, Military, Economics, and Art.
In order to educate someone in history or motivate an interest in history you're going to have to find out their "genre", whatever "lens" they view society and history through. For me it was agriculture. I'm endlessly fascinated by agricultural development, progress, trends, economy, the production and distribution of food, why people eat x, y, and z, but not a, b, or c, etc.. As long as history is presented to me through the filter of agriculture I'll pay attention and contextualize the information presented to me. You start talking about CROPS and things make sense to me.

This is also the biggest mistake people make when trying to get others interested in history is the inability to step out of their genre. A lot of history buffs are militaryeaboos and I, and a lot of other people (especially women), just do not give a shit about military campaigns, conquest, generals, etc.

>>14389542
Get her some female figures’ biographies. Not queenslay girlbosses mind you, but people like Sissi or Marie Antoinette or whichever other pampered princess who got involved in some drama. That’s phase 1.

Phase 2 is to get her light historical fiction books, like historical crime novels. E.g. the Shardlake series, or the Yashim the Eunuch series.

Phase 3 is actual fictionalized history such Robert Harris’ books. That’s probably as far as you’ll get when it comes to readings, don’t expect her to find an interest in actual accounts of historical events, and especially not in men’s biographies (unless they were moody rebellious figures), but at least you’ll now be able to take her to a museum without her dragging her feet.

Keep in mind you will never, ever, ever, get her to a point where she can discuss the French tax policies from the end of the Carolingian era to the contemporary era, but you she may start asking genuine questions about History, which is always good.

Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
don't ever try to drill historical dates into somebody unless they are already interested in history and it allows them to better understand things.
What's more important is to know how historical eras and specific notable events mesh into a larger history. So If she doesn't know when Rome existed, it would be useful to her to know at the least, that the medieval period that she would be vaguely familiar with was post-rome, and you could show her some media about pre-roman or contemporary to roman Gallic France or Native England, essentially showing that western european history can be told pre- and post-roman influence. In the process of this you could also casually debunk the king arthur and round table of knights stories whenever that comes up, and instead watch a historical drama more accurate to the political structure of the day, and who was actually ruling back then rather than a bunch of gallant knights.
>>14390109 this post is very true, and period dramas can be very good at centering a compelling emotional story in the middle of an important event that you might otherwise not care about. As long as you don't care a lot about teaching what years what events took place in, you should be able to impart the emotional importance of major historical events simply by exposing her to those compelling emotional stories, and commenting on how certain things shaped that moment that the character lived through, and so on.

>The Ili Rebellion (simplified Chinese: 伊宁事变; traditional Chinese: 伊寧事變; pinyin: Yīníng shìbiàn) (Üch Wiläyt inqilawi[3]) was a Soviet-backed revolt against the Kuomintang government of the Republic of China in 1944. Following the rebellion, the rebels established the Provisional Government of the Second East Turkestan Republic in 1944. The Ili Rebellion was the start of the Three Districts Revolution (simplified Chinese: 三区革命; traditional Chinese: 三區革命; pinyin: Sān qū gémìng) which lasted from 1944 to 1949.

>The Soviet Union installed Sheng Shicai as its puppet ruler in Xinjiang in the 1934 Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang and later further entrenched its position in the Islamic rebellion in Xinjiang (1937). Soviet Red Army forces were stationed in Xinjiang oases, such as the Soviet "Eighth Regiment" in Hami, and Soviet technicians and engineers flooded the province. During World War II the Kuomintang government of the Republic of China sought to undermine the Soviet presence in Xinjiang and retake the province from Soviet control. The Kuomintang worked with the Hui Muslim Ma Clique warlord of Qinghai, Gen. Ma Bufang, to build up its military forces around Xinjiang and increase the pressure on Sheng Shicai and the Soviets.

At the outset, U.S. officials viewed developments in China with ambivalence. On the one hand, they opposed Japanese incursions into northeast China and the rise of Japanese militarism in the area, in part because of their sense of a longstanding friendship with China. On the other hand, most U.S. officials believed that it had no vital interests in China worth going to war over with Japan. Moreover, the domestic conflict between Chinese Nationalists and Communists left U.S. policymakers uncertain of success in aiding such an internally divided nation. As a result, few U.S. officials recommended taking a strong stance prior to 1937, and so the United States did little to help China for fear of provoking Japan. U.S. likelihood of providing aid to China increased after July 7, 1937, when Chinese and Japanese forces clashed on the Marco Polo Bridge near Beijing, throwing the two nations into a full-scale war. As the United States watched Japanese forces sweep down the coast and then into the capital of Nanjing, popular opinion swung firmly in favor of the Chinese. Tensions with Japan rose when the Japanese Army bombed the U.S.S. Panay as it evacuated American citizens from Nanjing, killing three. The U.S. Government, however, continued to avoid conflict and accepted an apology and indemnity from the Japanese. An uneasy truce held between the two nations into 1940.

The United States was the main supplier of the oil, steel, iron, and other commodities needed by the Japanese military as it became bogged down by Chinese resistance but, in January, 1940, Japan abrogated the existing treaty of commerce with the United States. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chien-Shiung_Wu
>Chien-Shiung Wu (simplified Chinese: 吴健雄; traditional Chinese: 吳健雄; pinyin: Wú Jiànxióng; May 31, 1912 – February 16, 1997) was a Chinese-American experimental physicist who made significant contributions in the field of nuclear physics. Wu worked on the Manhattan Project, where she helped develop the process for separating uranium metal into uranium-235 and uranium-238 isotopes by gaseous diffusion. She is best known for conducting the Wu experiment, which contradicted the hypothetical law of conservation of parity. This discovery resulted in her colleagues Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen-Ning Yang winning the 1957 Nobel Prize in physics, and earned Wu the inaugural Wolf Prize in Physics in 1978. Her expertise in experimental physics evoked comparisons to Marie Curie. Her nicknames include "the First Lady of Physics", "the Chinese Madame Curie", and the "Queen of Nuclear Research".[1]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qian_Xuesen
>Qian Xuesen, or Hsue-Shen Tsien (Chinese: 钱学森; 11 December 1911 – 31 October 2009), was a prominent Chinese aerodynamicist and cyberneticist who contributed to rocket science and established engineering cybernetics. Recruited from MIT, he joined Theodore von Karman's group at Caltech.[1] Later, he returned to China and made important contributions to China's missile and space program.

>>14390352
Depends on the type of anarchism.

Individualist anarchy (including ancapism) is the concept that there should be no coercion of any kind, all thing should happen with mutual consent. That meand no law-enforcement at all and no laws that apply to everyone. What supposedly stops it from falling into total chaos is that everyone just decides to keep the non-agression principle, which is pure fantasy.

Collectivist anarchy is more feasable. Basically it just means an extremely democratized society, where people vote on everything. But unlike in individualist anarchy, everyone has to abide by these decisions, even if they disagree with them, otherwise the rest of society can enforce them.

In practice, an anarchist society would be extremely conservative and dogmatic. Without hierarchy, the only thing that could keep people in check would be tradition and peer pressure. You can see this today in tribal societies, which are actually quite egalitarian, and have traditions that punish success (to prevent new hierarchies from forming) and deviancy.

>>14390790
The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution, awarded both the Pulitzer and the Bancroft prizes, has become a classic of American historical literature. Hailed at its first appearance as “the most brilliant study of the meaning of the Revolution to appear in a generation,” it was enlarged in a second edition to include the nationwide debate on the ratification of the Constitution, hence exploring not only the Founders’ initial hopes and aspirations but also their struggle to implement their ideas in constructing the national government.
>>14391598
Now, in a new preface, Bernard Bailyn reconsiders salient features of the book and isolates the Founders’ profound concern with power. In pamphlets, letters, newspapers, and sermons they returned again and again to the problem of the uses and misuses of power―the great benefits of power when gained and used by popular consent and the political and social devastation when acquired by those who seize it by force or other means and use it for their personal benefit.
>>14391619
This fiftieth anniversary edition will be welcomed by readers familiar with Bailyn’s book, and it will introduce a new generation to a work that remains required reading for anyone seeking to understand the nation’s historical roots.

>>14393386
Psalm 9 was the first one the Bible ascribes to him that I memorized. I also like Psalm 18 a lot, since it appears basically twice in the Bible, see 2 Samuel chapter 22 and compare. We learn that David wrote Psalm 2 according to Acts 4:25 and that's a really good one. Psalm 110 was written by David and it is one of the most quoted in the New Testament (along with 118). Psalm 32 - also by David - is a good example of a Psalm with the Gospel message in it. Psalm 37 is a passage that many including myself find very calming, which is also another one of these Psalms. Psalm 72 is a good one about Solomon and about a righteous king in general, which was dedicated by David to Solomon. Psalm 131 and 133 are nice short Psalms by David, and I have always suspected that Psalm 132 was written by Solomon and arranged to be between these two, maybe as sort of a dedication to king David.

Psalms 25, 34, 37, 111, 112 and 145 are all acrostic and ascribed by the Bible to David. The other major acrostic Psalm is 119, which actually has 22 groupings of verses eight verses long, where all eight verses start with the same letter in Hebrew - although that one is unascribed. Other Biblical writers have also used acrostics, such as in Proverbs 31:10-31, and the first four chapters of Lamentations.

I don't think that's a good answer here. I've argued with many christards and they seem to think burden of proof is a totally artificial rule made up by atheists. and, to be honest, it does sound that way. first of all, it is incorrectly named; it might be better used in sentences like "the party wanting to be believed has the burden of proof", as that is the party that wants to convince the other side.
burden of proof was coined by IE speakers who have no notion of a negative copula. uralic languages, like my native language, seriously muddy the waters by making 'there's no god' a formally positive claim, because there's no formal negation in there, and if you try to argue that the meaning is negative, then the theist can retort that if we go by meaning and not grammatical formality when deciding whether a claim is a(n universal) negative, then we should simply say that "there's no god" has the meaning / is a mere rephrasing of "the world is entirely made of not-god".
imo the correct approach is to ask which party would have an easier task proving its position, and treat failure of producing such proof as disproof. besides this usually reducing to the aristotelian universal negative, it also sidesteps the grammatical formalities, and catches the christian in the fork of either not being able to prove a consequential god or having to preach an inconsequential one, with the added stain of modern theology consisting principally of efforts to turn said god truly inconsequential.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One of the main goals for semi-sedentary Native American tribes in a war was to displace the populations of neighboring tribes. What these semi-sedentary tribes valued was empty land, that is, land without any people living on it. Because that's where the wild game went once it had been hunted out of the areas immediately around the native settlement. It's also where wild forage was most abundant, because there was nobody gathering it. This empty land is known as a "buffer zone", and native tribes of any size would generally have a huge buffer zone of several square miles around their core settlements. This is why a lot of North America appeared "uninhabited", really it was just vast tracks of carefully emptied buffer territory. The natives would hunt one part of their territory at a time, and allow it to repopulate and regrow when they moved on to the next.

So if you need more food cause your tribe is getting bigger, you started hunting in somebody else's buffer territory, which naturally leads to conflict, and when the conflict gets bad enough you start raiding their settlement. Most of the time this wasn't to actually kill everybody, just force them to move away so you can absorb their buffer territory as your own.

So really, what the Americans did to the Natives wasn't really anything out of the ordinary for how they had experienced warfare among their own people for a long time. The only real tragedy is that they were hopelessly outmatched, technologically, and organizationally, once the colonists finally got their shit together and could field proper armies against them, instead of ragamuffin militias.

The Schutzstaffel was part of the party, not the official government like the Wehrmacht. The Nazi party and its associated organizations were a sort of parallel government to the "official" government which was inherited from the Weimar and Imperial German government. The demarcations of power were never clear, and Hitler purposefully made it so different ministers would be pitted against each other for influence.

Nazi Germany was a messy, bureaucratic monstrosity which derived power from one man's whims.
What really was important was not what post in government or in the party you officially held, but whether you had the personal attention of the Fuhrer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14390470
>invents linguistics and formal systems (Pāṇini)
This is an understatement. Pāṇini's theory of morphological analysis was more advanced than any equivalent Western theory before the 20th century. His treatise is generative and descriptive, uses metalanguage and meta-rules, and has been compared to the Turing machine wherein the logical structure of any computing device has been reduced to its essentials using an idealized mathematical model. Pāṇini's work became known in 19th-century Europe, where it influenced modern linguistics initially through Franz Bopp, who mainly looked at Pāṇini. Subsequently, a wider body of work influenced Sanskrit scholars such as Ferdinand de Saussure, Leonard Bloomfield, and Roman Jakobson. Pāṇini, and the later Indian linguist Bhartrihari, had a significant influence on many of the foundational ideas proposed by Ferdinand de Saussure, professor of Sanskrit, who is widely considered the father of modern structural linguistics and with Charles S. Peirce on the other side, to semiotics

Everything always boils back down to Geography with humans.

>The Declaration and Treaty on the Formation of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russian: Дeклapaция и дoгoвop oб oбpaзoвaнии Coюзa Coвeтcких Coциaлиcтичecких Pecпyблик) officially created the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), commonly known as the Soviet Union. It de jure legalised a political union of several Soviet republics that had existed since 1919 and created a new federal government whose key functions were centralised in Moscow. Its legislative branch consisted of the Congress of Soviets of the Soviet Union and the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union (TsIK), while the Council of People's Commissars composed the executive.

>The Treaty, along with the Declaration of the Creation of the USSR was approved on 30 December 1922 by a conference of delegations from the Russian SFSR, the Transcaucasian SFSR, the Ukrainian SSR and the Byelorussian SSR. The treaty provided flexibility to admit new members. Therefore, by 1940 the Soviet Union grew from the founding four (or six, depending on whether 1922 or 1940 definitions are applied) republics to 15 republics.

>>14394497
If we looked at all the Indian dynasties ever, and categorized them by caste rule, you'd see Brahmins under Kshatriyas, Shudras, and Vaishyas.

The vedas are clear on this: Brahmins aren't rulers. They aren't landowners, warriors, or wealthy merchants. The Brahmins were expected to be pious, frugal, and uninterested in power. The most accomplished Brahmins in Indian history were those who wrote massive Hindu epics and treaties on a variety of subjects, under the patronage of Kshatriya or Shudra kings. That being said, there were a few prominent Brahmin dynasties in North India worth mentioning. But they were minor in the grand scheme of things.

When you actually look at the inscriptions and primary sources found across India, it becomes clear that the Kshatriya-Shudra caste was responsible for almost every temple, university, army, and city construction. In times of peace you'd have warriors becoming farmers and owning land. These people are called "landed middle caste" in most regions of India and they were the most wealthy Indians under the British Raj. If war ever sprung up, the Shudras would become Kshatriyas. That's why you see so much genetic overlap, aside from a few outlier populations. Even today, the landed middle caste has a lot of nepotism and power in Indian politics and economics.

When NBC commissioned a prime-time program about Satan worship narrated by Geraldo Rivera, they had hopes for a sure-fire ratings winner. But the show, which was broadcast last night, stirred such stout advertiser resistance that the network had to sell some commercials at rates as low as half-price, advertisers and NBC officials said.

Beyond that, the program caused a sharp debate within NBC, where many - particularly at NBC News -felt that the program was below the standards of the network. The show met so much opposition in some corners of the network that NBC's own morning program, the ''Today'' show, refused to allow Mr. Rivera on the air to promote it.

''The subject matter was inappropriate to the morning,'' said Marty Ryan, executive producer of ''Today.''

The challenge to the NBC sales team was apparently a stiff one. Some advertising buyers said NBC began by asking $150,000 for a 30-second spot, and by this week was offering them for as little as $75,000. One NBC executive, who asked not to be identified, said NBC would give away some of the advertising time in the show as ''make-goods'' - making up to advertisers for past programs that failed to reach guaranteed audience levels. The eight kids sitting in Geraldo Rivera’s New York studio after the first McMartin trial ended could have stepped out of a candy bar commercial on Saturday morning TV. They gleamed with the healthy tans, shopping-mall clothes, and moussed sun-bleached hair of the southern California suburbs; their parents looked equally affluent. But these families were far from cheerful. “We were molested,” a strapping blond teenager told the audience solemnly, “and that’s an honest-to-God fact.” When some of the children – most of them by now adolescents – described suffering flashbacks and night terrors, their mothers quietly dabbed at tears.

even though the jury had completely exonerated Peggy McMartin Buckey while acquitting her son Ray on most counts and deadlocking on the rest, Geraldo’s guests insisted their former teachers really were sadistic sex criminals.

Geraldo reminded the audience that defendants are innocent until proven guilty. But he also asked whether the acquittals spelled doom for child abuse prosecutions, and titled the program “The McMartin Outrage: What Went Wrong?” Finally, when he patted the children’s shoulders and remarked on their “sincere pain,” it was clear this show was adding to the pressures that would lead to the current retrial of Ray Buckey on eight counts involving three girls.

What Geraldo neglected to mention was that none of these children had ever taken the stand: since McMartin first hit the media in 1984, his guests’ accusations had been so consistently bizarre and illogical that their testimony would only have damaged the case.

Not surprisingly, then, Freud’s theories of sexuality were later just as simplistically attacked by feminists eager to conflate sexuality with male violence. Their criticisms were most forcefully articulated in 1984, with the publication of Jeffrey Masson’s The Assault on Truth: Freud’s Suppression of the Seduction Theory.

And even as Masson institutionalized Freud-bashing, women and children were telling therapists and police rococo tales about sadomasochistic, diabolical assaults. How could these bizarre stories be true? But then, hadn’t we learned that sex abuse was much more common than previously thought?

In 1983, as part of his upcoming, hotly contested reelection campaign, the Los Angeles district attorney commissioned a survey asking voters to name their biggest crime concerns. He was surprised to learn that their main worry wasn’t drugs or drunken driving – it was child abuse. At about the same time the pollsters were at work, a mentally ill mother was telling Los Angeles County authorities Story-of-O tales about the McMartin preschool. Following her first accusations, police sent 200 letters to parents, listing specific questions to ask their children about whether and how Ray Buckey molested them. Virtually all the children denied being abused. Nevertheless, at the suggestion of the prosecution, panicked families made appointments at the Children’s Institute International (CII), a Los Angeles abuse therapy clinic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14392728
There, social workers plied the children with puppets, suggested ritual abuse scenarios, coaxed recalcitrant kids to “pretend,” and said that if they didn’t tell the “yucky secret” it meant they were stupid. This interviewing method followed from Los Angeles psychiatrist Roland Summit’s “child sexual abuse accommodation syndrome,” a theory about incest. Summit argues that if there is evidence of sex abuse and a child denies it, this is only further proof that it happened and a therapist should use any means necessary to help the child talk. When this technique was applied to criminal investigation, there wasn’t supposed to be any problem with false allegations. Research has since suggested that as many as one in twelve sex abuse reports are fabricated, that in divorce custody disputes, the rate may be as high as one in two, and that a disturbingly common source of false allegations is mentally ill mothers who injure their children, even genitally, to get attention. But in 1984, few were thinking about such issues – conventional wisdom was that since children are innocent beings, they never lie about sexual abuse. If they later recant, that means they are under family pressure to protect the father – and their turnabout is further proof of the crime.
